bibl.title: Letter from Emmett I. Vaughn to Michael E. Connor, December 6, 1924

div1.p: Vaughn discusses possible yellow fever cases in British Honduras. He encloses a copy of his report.

div1.head: Letter from Emmett I. Vaughn to Michael E. Connor, December 6, 1924
div1.opener:
Stann Creek, British Honduras,
December 6, 1924.
Dr. M. E. Connor,
Director for Central America,
Guatemala City.
Dear Dr. Connor:
div1.p:
I beg to acknowledge receipt of your two letters from San
Salvador dated December 22, enclosing copy of letter from Dr. Noguchi.
I note re. obtaining sera from the convalescents and sending same to
Dr. Muller in San Salvador. Of the two convalescents only one is
here now - the child Adolfo Mena. The other, Luciano Gamboa, an employee
of the lumber camp has not returned to duty as yet and no one seems to know
where he is. As the camp will not be running to its full capacity until
about January 12 I will check up the employees in the camp to see if he
is there. The camp opened on January 5 (yesterday) but Gamboa did not
report for duty. In the meantime I am going to Punta Gorda where I shall
remain a few days and on my return try to find Gamboa again. Did you
receive my cable to you sent to Elmendorf (there is no telegraph service)
in code reading more or less as follows: “Nothing new has occurred -
of the three cases yellow fever reported one not yellow fever - other two
considered doubtful.” This cable was addressed to “Intercom-Guatemala”
and sent on December 29. If the cable office does not have it try the
wireless.

Dr. Wilson received on, or about, December 26 from the I. H. B.
the following cable - “Examine autopsy tissues does not confirm diagnosis
yellow fever - in fact makes it extremely doubtful - hope for additional
information from examination sera convalescents.” This rather confirms
my cable to you of the 29th. I am leaving no stone unturned to prove
clinically and epidemiologically that these cases were or were not
yellow fever. At present all of the evidence is strongly in favor of
their not being yellow fever. I am enclosing you another section of my
report by which you will see that there is a possibility if this man
Ricketts is at all suspicious attention will have to be directed to the
northern part of the colony - especially around Corozal the port of entry
from all adjacent Mexican territory to the north. You might be interested
to know that upon my arrival here I found that Dr. Harwood still retained
the viscera of the fatal case of yellow fever (?) and I had him send
sections of same to Belize from which place they were sent to New York so
that there will be a second set of tissues to examine. These last tissues
were in formalin and not in alcohol as the first lot sent to New York. I
have an idea that Ricketts trail may lead to a man named Ramirez from Payo
Obispo who left here on December 13 and has not returned. It has taken
days to find some of the men and one time it took five police over five
days to find a man here in Stann Creek for me. As I stand at present the
only thing that will convince me that Menas case was yellow fever is a
positive diagnosis from New York. If I had been fortunate enough to have
seen these cases during their illness the diagnosis might have been
settled long ago - I say “might” for one can never be certain in these
things.
